{{Infobox National football team | Name = Malaysia U-23 | Badge = Football Association of Malaysia crest.svg | Badge_size = 135 px | FIFA Trigramme = MAS | Nickname = ''Harimau Muda''
(Young Tigers) | Association = [[Football Association of Malaysia]] | Coach = {{flagicon|Malaysia}} [[Ong Kim Swee]] | Asst Manager = | Captain = [[Khairul Fahmi Che Mat]] | Home Stadium = [[National Stadium, Bukit Jalil]] | Most caps = | Top scorer = | pattern_la1=_malaysia10h|pattern_b1=_MAS10h|pattern_ra1=_malaysia10h|pattern_sh1=_yellowsides|pattern_so1=_mal10h | leftarm1=000000|body1=FFD700|rightarm1=000000|shorts1=000000|socks1=FFD700 | pattern_la2=_malaysia10a|pattern_b2=|pattern_ra2=_malaysia10a|pattern_sh2=_usa10h|pattern_so2=_caen1011h | leftarm2=0033FF|body2=0033FF|rightarm2=0033FF|shorts2=FFFFFF|socks2=0033FF | First game = {{flagicon|Malaysia}} Malaysia 5–0 [[Philippines national under-23 football team|Philippines]] {{flagicon|Philippines}}
([[Seoul]], [[South Korea]]; May 20, 1991) | Largest win = {{flagicon|MAS}} Malaysia 8–1 [[Cambodia national under-23 football team|Cambodia]] {{flagicon|Cambodia}}
([[Ho Chi Minh City|Ho Chi Minh]], [[Vietnam]]; November 29, 2003)
{{flagicon|MAS}} Malaysia 11–0 [[Timor-Leste national under-23 football team|Timor-Leste]] {{flagicon|Timor Leste}}
([[Vientiane]], [[Laos]]; December 2, 2009) | Largest loss = {{fbu|23|Thailand}} 9–0 Malaysia {{flagicon|MAS}}
([[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]]; November 1998) | Regional name = [[SEA Games]] | Regional cup apps = 4 | Regional cup first = 2001 | Regional cup best = [[File:Med 1.png|Gold Medalist]] 1st, [[Football at the 2009 Southeast Asian Games|2009]] & [[Football at the 2011 Southeast Asian Games|2011]] }} '''Malaysia national under-23 football team''' (also known as '''Malaysia Under-23''', '''Malaysia U-23''' or '''Malaysia Olympic Team''') represents [[Malaysia]] in international [[football (soccer)|football]] competitions in [[Olympic Games]], [[Asian Games]] and [[SEA Games]], as well as any other under-23 international football tournaments. They are the strongest under-23 team in Southeast Asia, after winning the [[Football at the 2009 Southeast Asian Games|2009]] and [[Football at the 2011 Southeast Asian Games|2011 SEA Games]] gold medal. Their main rivals are [[Indonesia national under-23 football team|Indonesia]] and [[Singapore national under-23 football team|Singapore]]. The team is controlled by the [[Football Association of Malaysia]]. ==History== The team is considered to be the feeder team for the [[Malaysia national football team]]. It is for players aged 23 and less, however 3 senior players can also be selected to play. Also in existence are national teams for Under-20s, Under-17s and Under-15s. As long as they are eligible, players can play at any level, hence it is possible for one to play for the U-23s, senior side and then again for the U-23s. ===Olympic 2000=== After the [[1997 FIFA World Youth Championship]], [[Football Association of Malaysia]] (FAM) aiming to qualify for the 2000 Sydney Olympic. Thus, the [[Football Association of Malaysia|FAM]] spent about US$6 million and continue the contract of Malaysia youth coach, [[Hatem Souissi]]. Then [[Football Association of Malaysia|FAM]] form a squad known as '''Olympic 2000''' with a combination of 1997 youth squad and other under 23 players. [[Football Association of Malaysia|FAM]] decided to include Olympic 2000 as one of the team in Malaysia League. Their first match was against [[Johor FA]] in qualification match for Malaysia Premier I League. The team won their first match away 1-0 before drawing 1-1 at home to qualify for Malaysia Premier I League. However the team finishes bottom during 1998 season with only 4 win in 22 matches.[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesm/malay97.html Malaysia 1998] The Olympic 2000 also show poor performance in international stage. They were humiliated by the [[Thailand national under-23 football team|Thailand Asian Games squad]] in a 1998 friendly match as the Thai's beat them 9-0. During the qualification matches, Olympic 2000 only manage to finish third behind Hong Kong and Japan. It is questionable among the fans how a squad who was playing together since 1995 given so much exposure and with fine talent cannot achieve the expectation. ==International scene== {{see|:Malaysia national football team}} The '''Malaysia national football team''' uses the same squad for the Under-23 team and the national team under the new management of [[Malay styles and titles|Datuk]] [[K. Rajagopal]]. Malaysia national football team uses players below the age of 23, together with their senior players like [[Mohd Safee Mohd Sali|Safee Sali]] and [[Mohd Norhafiz Zamani Misbah]]. This was set for the national team to prepare the challenges ahead of them. Malaysia used the Under-23 team for the upcoming tournament such as the Ho Chi Minh City Cup, [[2010 Asian Games]] and [[2010 AFF Suzuki Cup]].[http://www.fam.org.my/n.asp?id=92 Malaysia national squad for Ho Chi Minh Cup, Asian Games and 2010 AFF Suzuki Cup 2010] Malaysia used this way since the Football Association of Malaysia chairman, [[Ahmad Shah of Pahang|HRH Sultan Ahmad Shah]], planned this and set the plan mainly for K. Rajagopal. This is as a result after the humiliation lost 0-5 to the United Arab Emirates at the 2011 Asian Cup Qualifiers. ==Honours== * '''[[Football at the Southeast Asian Games|Southeast Asian Games]]''' ** [[File:Med 1.png]] '''Gold medal (2):''' [[Football at the 2009 Southeast Asian Games|2009]] and [[Football at the 2011 Southeast Asian Games|2011]] ** [[File:Med 2.png]] Silver medal (1): [[2001 Southeast Asian Games|2001]] ** [[File:Med 3.png]] Bronze medal (2): [[Football at the 2003 Southeast Asian Games|2003]] and [[Football at the 2005 Southeast Asian Games|2005]] * '''[[Merdeka Tournament]]''' ** [[File:Med 1.png]] '''Winner (1):''' 2007 ==Tournament records== ===Olympic Games=== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;font-size:90%;" !colspan=9|[[Football at the Summer Olympics|Olympic Games Record]] |- !Year !Round !Position !GP !W !D !L !GS !GA |- |{{flagicon|FRA}} [[Football at the 1900 Summer Olympics|1900]] to
